Tony Montana.Action: Answers questions briefly and with a hint of pride about his background despite evident hardship.
Responds to immigration officials with brief, confident answers despite harsh circumstances, showing controlled composure and self-presentation.
Wears ragged clothes and appears unkempt, reflecting his disadvantaged position but not diminishing his inner strength and determination.
Answers questions about his past with humor (grinning) and defiance.
Responds with aggression and disdain when questioned about sensitive topics (homosexuality).
Denies any past incarcerations or offenses firmly and confidently.
Maintains composure under intense questioning, gives confident and concise answers, uses humor to deflect
Appears visibly nervous through rapid eye movements and fidgeting
Explains the tattoo 'Madre' on his hand as a mark for his sweetheart.
Responds to interrogation with sarcasm and hostility, refuses to cooperate.
Deflects interrogation with sarcasm and bluster rather than clear, strategic answers.
Maintains a tough, confident demeanor when confronted, shows resilience under pressure.
Insists on dignity and demands human rights, claiming to be a political prisoner from Cuba.
Responds to mockery with a taunting smile, showing no hard feelings.
Jokes aggressively by saying 'So I'll sit in your lap' when told the seat is taken.
Uses defiant and sharp rhetoric to assert his identity and demand human rights, showing confidence and verbal skill under pressure.
Despite his eloquence, his plea falls on disbelieving ears and is met with ridicule, indicating limited influence or diplomatic skill in this context.
Takes the Baby Ruth bar from Manny and peels off the chocolate, returning the empty wrapper to Manny without offering any of it.
Corrects Manny sharply over what he told others about his health, criticizes him aggressively.
Corrects Manny's misinformation to the authorities, ensuring the story is clear and believable.
Shows frustration and anger towards Mannyâ€™s mistake but takes charge of the situation.
Fails to communicate effectively with Manny beforehand; relies on Manny to carry out critical information but ends up frustrated.
Expresses distrust toward everyone except Manny; tells Manny he loves him like a brother.
Wears a provocative 'Fuck Off and Die' button and boasts about never going crazy like others.
Displays increased confidence and self-assuredness as he adapts to his new environment, speaks English faster and more fluently, and shows awareness about paranoia around trust.
Acknowledges the danger of paranoia but insists he will not lose control or go crazy like others, demonstrating emotional self-control and resolve.
Expresses distrust towards everyone except Manny, showing selective trust and loyalty, implying strategic social awareness.
Playfully punches Manny and calls him like a brother, expressing love.
Dismissively responds to transvestite with sarcastic remark passing by.
Stares pensively at a snapshot of a young girl and a dog, showing a rare moment of repose and personal reflection.
Attempts to call someone on the outside but hangs up after an uncertain response, indicating hesitation or fear of connection.
Tells Angel not to waste money trying to find his brother, adding that his brother hates him.
Carefully dials a phone number written on a snapshot, attempts to make contact, but then prudently hangs up when unsure, showing hesitation and caution.
Ignores others pressing to use the phone and walks away at his own pace, indicating confidence and control over the situation.
Fails to follow through after connecting with an older woman on the phone, abruptly hanging up and showing uncertainty.
Dismisses Angel's desperate attempts to find his brother, giving a blunt, demoralizing remark.
Reassures others about their immigration situation, tries to calm their fears and encourages not to worry too much.
Assesses the immigration situation practically and confidently, dismissing panic and demonstrating understanding of systemic constraints and public visibility.
Downplays potential risks by assuring others not to worry excessively about possible worst-case delays.
Winks and smiles at Manny and Angel while enjoying music, playfully imitates a singer.
Gets up after being knocked down in a soccer game and brushes himself off without complaint.
Dismisses Angel's call to continue playing soccer, saying he has better things to do.
Initiates a private walk with Manny to hear good news.
Expresses confidence about their situation with 'You worry too much, mi hermano.'
Casually performs an awkward imitation and dances, showing charisma but not serious capability.
Fails to control the soccer ball and is physically outplayed by a younger kid, falling on his face.
Dismisses the game and focuses on more important matters when called.
Shows enthusiasm and positive attitude about getting a green card and a job in Miami, indicating optimism and readiness to seize opportunity.
Asks Manny what they have to do next, implying willingness to follow a plan and engage actively.
Signals Angel with a shake of the head to 'forget it', demonstrating quick decision-making and clear communication.
Expresses concern that Angel gets out with them, showing care for allies and strategic thinking about group strength.
Secures a Green Card through legal immigration processes, demonstrating determination and resourcefulness to establish himself in the U.S.
Confidently surveys his new environment and quickly assesses social dynamics (e.g., identifying a 'millionaire' and instructing Chico to ask for money), showing street smarts and adaptability.
Waves off a Cuban girl then quickly runs up to her and throws up her skirt, peeking at her.
Laughs at the girl's reaction while she and her friend curse him in Spanish.
Boasts to Manny about his ability to attract women by making a peculiar gesture with his tongue, implying women go crazy for him.
Waves off a girl rudely but then impulsively lifts her skirt and peeks at her, laughing; lacks subtlety and respect.
Tries to impress Manny by wiggling his tongue quickly but fails to perform it skillfully, causing laughter; shows a lack of agility and practice.
Checks himself multiple times in a shop window, indicating self-awareness and care about his appearance.
Demonstrates confidence in social interactions by persistently trying to charm women, despite rude behavior.
Makes funny faces to entertain a somber child, leading the child to smile and the mother to return a smile.
Stops traffic by sticking out his arm and shows no concern for the angry honking drivers.
Mocks Manny after the blonde slaps him and walks away.
Acknowledges he has friends who help him get jobs and connections.
Works hard side by side with Manny Ray, despite exhaustion and poor conditions.
Confidently asserts that his friends will take care of the job, showing trust in his connections and a self-assured attitude.
Works hard doing menial tasks like stubbing grease off pots and washing dishes, showing willingness to work and persistence despite low status.
Fails to prevent a dropped dish and shows exhaustion, indicating occasional lack of finesse or being overwhelmed.
Criticizes others for lacking character and being junkies despite their flashy appearance, reflects self-critically on his own rough hands
Introduces himself arrogantly, nods arrogantly instead of engaging warmly.
Dismisses unloading 25 tons of grass for $500 each, insults Omar and Waldo by implying the job is beneath him.
Shuts Omar down abruptly with 'Shaddup!'
Declines a low-paying job, asserting his perceived importance and value with confidence.
Refuses to participate in work he considers beneath him without clear evidence of alternative opportunities.
Responds aggressively and threateningly when called a 'dishwasher,' ready to fight.
Shrugs off a suggestion about hiring cheaper help, showing indifference.
Listens silently to Omar's plan to make big money from cocaine, shows willingness to cooperate.
Says to the cook 'Wash yourself. I just retired.' and throws him his apron, dismissing him brusquely.
Expresses fear with 'I'm scared.'
Dismisses Manny's worry by telling him 'You worry too much Manny -- you're gonna get yourself a heart attack one of these days.'
Shows racial intolerance by calling Colombians 'animals!'
Turns down the salsa beat on the radio, smokes a cigarette tensely, shows irritation and impatience when Angel is tense and the light changes, telling Manny to drive without much empathy.
Mocks Manny jokingly about getting a heart attack, shows some teasing behavior but not necessarily warm or kind.
Remains calm and focused while driving and handling a tense situation with his gang, showing situational awareness.
Mocking a gang member for worry despite the tension, demonstrating confidence and control.
Distracted by a teenage girl despite the tension, indicating a lack of full focus on the situation.
Angrily dismisses Angel's spiritual beliefs and mocks Afro-Catholic voodoo practices, insisting there are no gods and that one must make their own luck.
Gives clear, direct instructions to Manny and Angel about money and safety before entering the motel, taking responsibility for his own security.
Commands respect by dismissing superstition and asserting control, insisting on personal responsibility and setting clear rules about handling money and timing at the motel.
Displays impatience and anger by telling others to shut up, potentially alienating allies.
Greets the Toad warmly with 'How you doing amigo...?'
Indicates he is unarmed by spreading his hands as a sign of trust
Asks the Toad to leave the door open so 'my brothers know everything's okay'
Strategically arms his associate Manny with a high-powered machine pistol during the approach, indicating preparedness and tactical thinking.
Approaches the motel room calmly and initiates contact with the occupants in a cautious yet confident manner, showing control and awareness.
Symbolically shows he is unarmed when entering the room to avoid suspicion, demonstrating calculated social tactics.
Asks for the door to be left open as a signal to his men outside, showing organized communication and situational awareness.
Asks Toad to leave the door open so his brothers know everything's okay.
Interacts curtly and suspiciously with Toad and Marta, resists small talk about origins.
Engages in negotiation calmly, tries to verify details about the deal and people involved, casually checks surroundings, signals awareness and control of situation.
Uses dismissive and confrontational language when asked innocuous questions (e.g., about his origin), which may alienate business partners and undermine rapport.
Threatens Toad violently when accused of theft and shows no mercy.
Readily reaches for a gun when hearing a female's frightened shriek, indicating protectiveness.
Maintains calm and confidence when confronted and threatened, responds with defiance and verbal intimidation.
Is caught off guard and unarmed at first, handgun is stripped from him by Toad.
Displays clear understanding of the threat and uses verbal threats to assert dominance despite being temporarily disarmed.
Watches helplessly as Angel is tortured, does not intervene or show concern beyond anger at the situation.
Remains calm and defiant under threat, despite being restrained and facing imminent danger.
Allows himself to be captured and restrained without attempting escape or negotiation.
Expresses fury and tears when witnessing Angel being mutilated and killed.
Does not intervene or act to stop Angel's torture despite emotional reaction.
Expresses shock and rage but shows no expression or ability to stop the chainsaw attack on Angel; is restrained and led forward powerless.
Despite emotional turmoil (tears, fury), fails to prevent immediate threats or protect Angel, indicating lack of control or immediate problem-solving.
Spits in Toad's face when threatened and insulted.
Smashes kid two with the stock of his own Ingram while still partially restrained.
Kills kid two point-blank after he attacks, then calmly pursues and kills the Toad in cold fury.
Dances back narrowly avoiding a knife attack and quickly counters by shooting kid two point-blank.
Calmly and deliberately follows the wounded Toad into the parking lot, showing no fear, and kills him efficiently with a machine gun.
Checks on Manny after the shooting, asking if he is okay.
Calmly walks away from the violent scene with disinterest, concealing his identification.
Fingers Angel's change charm momentarily before tossing it back, showing brief, detached acknowledgment.
Insists on delivering the drug ('yeyo') to the boss himself instead of sending Omar, showing confidence and personal assertiveness.
Questions Omar about the quality of a previous pick-up, indicating awareness and attention to detail about operations.
Shows a quick temper by telling Omar to 'fuck you' over the phone, which may undermine efficient communication.
Politely greets Frank Lopez and accepts his offer for a drink using respectful language.
Glances at Omar and praises him as 'terrific' during conversation.
Offers money as a gift to Lopez, shows respect with a toast.
Is somewhat reserved and overwhelmed, only says 'Yeah.. well.'
Responds politely and with genuine admiration when introduced to Elvira, the beautiful woman.
Engages in light conversation with Lopez and others about Elvira, showing a subtle sense of humor and camaraderie.
No dismissive or rude behavior toward Elvira or others present; shows respectful politeness despite underlying tension.
Engages in light banter with Lopez, showing quick wit ('I guess you gotta catch her in the middle, hunh?').
Looks visibly impressed by Elvira, indicating possible distraction or awe upon meeting a beautiful woman.
Does not take initiative to steer the conversation or introduce himself confidently, responding with a simple 'Uh...hi.'
Laughs and claims 'I got nothing but friends' when Elvira suggests someone might want to kill him.
Listens to Lopez explain the dangers of greed and rivals, showing attentiveness and willingness to learn.
Does not interrupt or challenge Lopez's warnings about others being untrustworthy.
Listens attentively to Lopez's advice about the dangers of greed and competitors in the business.
Does not immediately show understanding of the term 'haza', indicating a gap in his cultural/business understanding.
Accepts praise and opportunity from Lopez with friendliness and enthusiasm, showing openness to collaboration.
Tastes liquor reverently, indicating appreciation and respect in social setting.
No evident dismissiveness or coldness towards others in this excerpt, maintains good interaction.
Accepts the offer to work on a big operation running a string of mules out of Colombia, showing willingness to take on responsibility and engage with experienced associates.
Only verbally agrees without demonstrating clear plans or strategic thinking in this excerpt, showing limited detailed initiative.
Walks to the dance floor bulldozing people without care.
Bumps into an elderly couple and ignores them.
Attempts to start conversation with Elvira to be friendly.
Walks through the club floor with unstoppable confidence, like a tank, clearly focused and undeterred by obstacles.
Bumps into an elderly couple dancing and ignores them, showing a disregard for social tact or awareness.
Leads Elvira onto the dance floor and attempts friendly conversation despite being a poor dancer.
Attempts to be friendly initially by approaching Elvira.
Responds angrily to Elvira's insult and unintentionally harms elderly couple while annoyed.
Makes a crude and intrusive remark to Elvira about her sexual life.
Watches Elvira leave, amused by her anger but does not escalate conflict.
Casually asserts that a woman loves him, showing confidence but possibly arrogance.
Dismisses threat from Lopez despite Manny's concerns, showing bravado but lack of caution for others' safety.
Carries a bag of gifts to his mother's house, nervous but thoughtful.
Identifies Lopez as 'soft' despite warning about Lopez's lady and potential threat, showing overconfidence but assessing opponent's weakness.
Confidently reads a woman's feelings through her eyes, demonstrating social intuition and confidence.
Driving home in a broken-down sedan after partying all night, showing lack of preparation or disregard for practical matters.
Prepares to visit his mother carrying gifts and spruced up in a new suit, indicating planning and respect for social/family roles.
Talks openly with Manny about ambitions and frustrations, sharing dreams about the future.
Dismisses and disparages Frank's organization, calling it inferior and calling Manny a 'chickenhead' for valuing Frank's support.
Waves off a girl brusquely, then changes his mind and runs up behind her to peek under her skirt and laughs at her shocked reaction.
Invites two young girls to have ice cream with him and Manny.
Derides organizational structure, asserts he has more brains than bigger rivals, showing overconfidence and dismissiveness.
Displays juvenile, disrespectful behavior towards women by lifting a girl's skirt and laughing, resulting in negative reactions.
Demonstrates quick awareness and perception with subtle gestures (the 'baby robin's head' flick) and teaches Manny about this nonverbal signal.
Attempts to perform a skill (speed and agility) but fails and provokes laughter from others.
Confidently points out and expresses interest in a woman across the avenue, showing social boldness.
Fails to yield or stop when causing traffic disruption, angrily waving arms at cars that ignore him.
